fields.summary: Is there a way to change the company's favicon on our actual Confluence 4.3 version? Thank you!

fields.description:
Events which cover Daylight Savings change do not reflect properly in the Team Calendar Macro List View.

To reproduce:

* Add an all day calendar entry for October 25th - October 27th
* Add the Team Calendar macro to a page
* Edit it to use list view

Result:  You will see one entry for October 25th, and two entries for October 26th (screenshot attached).
fields.summary: Events which cover Daylight Savings change do not reflect properly in the Team Calendar Macro List View

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48992].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to replicate

# Install confluence 5.6.6, with latest team Calendar
# Create about 80 or more events in the same month
# Print it out the Firefox 40 default printer

h5. Expected Behavior
All event are printed out

h5. Actual Behavior
Only first 2 weeks's event are rendered in the printing

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48988].
  {panel}

h3. After you add a JIRA event to a Team Calendar there is no Delete option as there is with other events

h3. Reproduced in Cloud, version 5.2.16-D20150624T084818
(Reported by customer on Server version)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a JIRA Event to a Team Calendar
# Click on the event, no delete option is there

h3. Expected Results: 
Delete option would be there as it is for a regular event

h3. Actual Results
No Delete option displayed

h3.Workaround
Remove the Event from the list of events on the right of the calendar as shown in the screen shot:  !TCremoveevent.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: No Delete option on JIRA Events after they are added to Team Calendar

fields.description:
Team Calendar does not display the time and date correctly if the Jira event starts and end at the *same time* regardless if it's on a different day.
Refer to  [^teamcalendar.mp4] for the replication steps

h3. *Environment*
- Jira 7
- Confluence 5.9.4
- Team Calendar 5.3.11

h3. *Steps to replicate*
# Create an application link between Confluence and Jira
# Go to Jira Admin>> Issue >> Custom Field and insert 2 Date Time Picker (name it "start" and "end")
# Create an issue in Jira and insert the start date and end date 1 day apart with the same time. Example
#- Start
{code}
16/Aug/16 8:00 AM
{code}
#- End
{code}
17/Aug/16 8:00 AM
{code}
# Go to Confluence, Team Calendar >> Create an event under type "Jira Issues Date" and select the project that you've created. Add the date range with start and end accordingly.
# Save it and refresh. Note that the calendar shows only 1 day which is 16/Aug/16 and the duration is shown as whole day.
# If the end time& date is changed to anything apart from the *exact start and end time*, it's displaying correctly.
#- Example
{panel}
17/Aug/16 7:59 AM
17/Aug/16 8:01 AM
{panel}

h3. *Workaround*
Use a different end time (additional 1 minute or so)
fields.summary: Jira Date Time Picker integration shows as All Day Event regardless of date
Error message:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48984].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Users who use Team Calendars for the first time will see the tour bus guide. However, if license is expired, tour bus guide cannot appear and cause spinner spins forever.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Team Calendars into Confluence and add an expired license.
# Although license is expired but it's still valid. Start to visit My Calendar.

h3. Expected Result
My Calendar page should show license error message without other implicit errors.

h3. Actual Result
There are implicit errors in the javascript and spinner doesn't disappear. See the attachment.
fields.summary: Calendar Tour Bus cause javascript error if licence is expired

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48983].
  {panel}

After updating some plugins (and the universal plugin Manager plugin), the Team calendar wont start any more:
This add-on couldn't be loaded. It has one or more errors that prevent it from being enabled.

So i thougth, that an uninstall and a new install would resolve this.

Now my question:
When i reinstalling the team calender, will the calendar items still remain?
Or is everything (calendars, calender items, ...) lost?
Thanks in advance!
fields.summary: when i reinstalling the team calender, will the calendar items still remain?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48982].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Trying to subscribe to a calendar doesn't generate the necessary link (the field is blank)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create or go to an existing calendar
# Click the 3 dots after the name of the calendar on the right and select the "_Subscribe_" option

h3. Expected Results
A link should be generated and displayed in the field
h3. Actual Results
The field is blank
h3.Workaround
If possible, go to Team Calendars' Global Settings and select the "_Disable Private URLs_" check box then try to subscribe to it again.
fields.summary: Subscribe to calendar doesn't create link
Team Calendars and Mac Calendar does not integrate properly (Timezone)
Fix https://sdog.jira.com/browse/PIPE-168#

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48978].
  {panel}

So far, it's been a pretty bad experience trying to get this plugin working. Trying to create a Calendar now results in the following error:

There was a SQL exception thrown by the Active Objects library: Database: - name:Oracle - version:Oracle Database 11g Enterprise Edition Release 11.1.0.7.0 - 64bit Production With the Partitioning, OLAP, Data Mining and Real Application Testing options - minor version:1 - major version:11 Driver: - name:Oracle JDBC driver - version:11.1.0.7.0-Production java.sql.SQLException: An SQLException was provoked by the following failure: java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 11

Since about version 4.2 we've not been able to create Calendars. This error message was not previously displayed, the Create Calendar dialog would remain after clicking the button, but the AJAX response was some similar status 500 error message. So at least displaying an error message is a step in the right direction.

I've tried doubling the Java heap space, as that was the only advice I could find to resolve ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

In production we reverted to Team Calendars 4.1.4, as this was the last known working version (we evaluated this version and it worked). Since we purchased the product, none of the more recent versions have been working for us so we're sticking with version 4.1.4 and monitoring the situation on our dev server.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48925].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When a user whose name contains double quote characters is an ORGANIZER of an event, when an export to ICS is done, the ORGANIZER line is both improperly quoted, and the wrong length for line folding. The quote gets converted to a HTML entity i.e. &quot; which contains the illegal character semi-colon, and additionally the line length is treated as if it still took up only one character, so it wraps after longer than 75 characters. Note that for unaffected lines Team Calendar also seems to be wrapping at 73 characters instead of 75, which while valid, is not necessary.

As per the [RFC 2445|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2445#section-4.8.4.3], a double quote character is actually illegal except for quoting other characters, but additionally a semi-colon is an illegal character for a parameter value unless it's contained in a quote or escaped. It's not possible to escape a double quote as part of the parameter value, which must be why it's converted into a HTML entity.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a calendar
# Create an event with an organizer whose name contains at least one double quote character
# Export the calendar

h3. Expected Results

A valid ICS file

h3. Actual Results

The file is not valid ICS.

h3.Workaround

Manually edit the ICS file, locating the lines containing &quot; and modify the CN to be quoted, then re-do the line folding such that the line does not exceed 75 octets.

For example the following invalid entry:

{noformat}
ORGANIZER;X-CONF-USERNAME=username;CN="User Name":mailto:username@exampl
 e.com
{noformat}

Can be converted to this valid entry:

{noformat}
ORGANIZER;X-CONF-USERNAME=username;CN=""User Name"":mailto:user
 name@example.com
{noformat}

Alternatively, if you avoid having any users with names containing a double quote character, then you will not encounter this issue.
fields.summary: Export to ICS is in an invalid format if a username contains a double quote

h3. Summary

The *Select Groups* button does not work when attempting to add group restrictions to a calendar.

h3. Environment

* Confluence 5.10.0
* Confluence 5.9.5
* Confluence 6.8.1
* Team Calendars 5.3.11
* Team Calendars 6.0.0
* Team Calendars 6.0.27
* Google Chrome

(May affect other versions)

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Open any calendar
# Click on the elipsis to open the configuration options for the calendar
# Select *Restrictions*
# Click on the *Group...* button
# Search for any group
# Mark the checkbox for the group and click on *Select Group(s)*

h3. Expected Results

Group is added to the restriction and pop-up window is closed.

h3. Actual Results

Nothing happens and pop-up window remains open.

h3. Workaround

- The user can restrict any user or group by adding their names directly in the text box prior to clicking the *Group...* button.
- Other browsers besides Google Chrome are working as expected but are extremely slow.
- Chrome works on incognito mode, however it is extremely slow
- This feature works well in Safari and it is quite fast

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48913].
  {panel}

Hi, 

We noticed that e-mail notifications about changes in a Confluence Team Calendar are still sent to team members who do not have permission to view or edit the calendar. 

*Context:* 
We are using Team Calendars to plan projects. One team will have several projects in a row and we want to use one Team Calendar for the different projects of one team. Each project is planned before it is signed off and released to the whole development team. There should be an option that enables us to not spam the whole team with changes made in the planning phase. Restricting a calendar is the obvious solution, but it doesn't work as expected.

*Steps to reproduce: *
1. All team members are watching a team space. 
2. A Team Calendar is added to this space. Some team members might even start watching the calendar directly.
3. Viewing and editing the calendar is restricted to only one team member. 

*Actual result:* Other team members are getting e-mail notifications about the changes made in the calendar even though they can't view it. 

*Expected result:* If viewing of a calendar is restricted, then the people not permitted to view the calendar should not get any e-mail notifications, even if they are watching the respective space/calendar.

It would be great, if this issue could be fixed - thank you :-)

PS: Please add a "Restrictions" component to the TEAMCAL project :-)
fields.summary: E-mail notifications sent to team members even though viewing restricted

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48910].
  {panel}

The contents of the 'subCalendarId' parameter is not validated in POST requests to 'subscribetocalendar.action' and is susceptible to cross-site scripting.

Steps to Reproduce:
# Start a proxy tool such as Burp Suite.
# Log into a Confluence instance with Team Calendars installed.
# Use the proxy tool to generate a POST request to '/confluence/calendar/subscribetocalendar.action' with the following payload:
{quote}POST /confluence/calendar/subscribetocalendar.action HTTP/1.1
Host: rgallagher:1990
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:41.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/41.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: http://rgallagher:1990/confluence/calendar/subscribetocalendar.action
Cookie: confluence-sidebar.width=285; JSESSIONID=E85F825667B40A9201910EE6FF9DF7EA; AJS.conglomerate.cookie=""
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 75

subCalendarId=<script>alert('XSS in subscribetocalendar.action')<%2fscript>{quote}
# Ensure that a valid value is sent in the 'JSESSIONID' cookie.
# Send the request from Burp Repeater, and view the output in the browser.
# The payload sent in the POST body is reflected in the HTTP response, and its JavaScript executes.

We've demonstrated the exploitability using Burp Suite because the customer who reported the vulnerability was unable to include steps to reproduce from the UI. An attacker could exploit this instance of cross-site scripting by inducing a user to click on a link which submits the malicious POST request to the victim's Confluence domain.
fields.summary: Cross-Site Scripting in subscribetocalendar.action

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48904].
  {panel}

When adding recurring calendar events the system indicates an incorrect date format, even though  the date was selected via the calendar widget and the format appears to be correct. The issue does not happen when creating single-day events. 
Troubleshooting seems to indicate that the issue is associated with setting an end date. If I don't set an end date then the recurring event is added to my calendar. I tried to use that as a work-around by then editing the recurring event to add an end date, but the end date option is apparently disabled during edit (though I don't know why that would be).

See screenshot.

This appears to be a recent bug, as I have been able to create recurring calendar events with end dates only a week or so back.

h3. Summary
As of the last update, customers are finding their events in Team Calendar for the month of December 2016 are missing.

h3. Environment
* Team Calendar 1000.0.1 in Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
If you have calendars setup in TC with events for each month, such as Nov 2016 and Dec 2016, you will find the events for December do not display.

h3. Expected Results
Events should display

h3. Actual Results
Events don't display

h3. Notes
Events will display in another calendar app such as Outlook, for example, so we know they're in the database and not lost.

h3.Workaround
Manually refresh each time you change the month. 
* Go to the calendar menu (3-dot button near the top right) > Click "Refresh"

- Disable all event types except Travel.

- Notice that now the event is DUPLICATED instead of edited. There's one for Leave and one for Travel.

h2. Problem summary
There is a conflict in jquery.ui.datepicker.js: one date picker is from AUI and the other from Team Calendars. This can cause problems in date picker pop-ups for third-party plugin functionality, such as editing page contents with the Scaffolding Plugin from ServiceRocket.

h2. Steps to reproduce
# Install Confluence 5.8.18, Team Calendars 5.3.11, Scaffolding Plugin 8.4.1
# Install the above Confluence and plugins (trial licenses are fine)
# Create a Confluence space and test page
# Add a "Date Data" macro. Give it any name, and set the date format to "MM-dd-yyyy"
# Save the page
# The page should now have an "Edit Contents" option. Click this to go into the Scaffolding Editor
# Click the calendar icon into the field

h2. Expected Behavior
Date picker should pop up, allowing users to configure both date and time

h2. Actual behavior
Date picker does not pop up, or a version of the date-only picker pops up without ability to set time. Using browser's developer console, the following error can be observed:

!console.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Team Calendars Date Picker conflicts with AUI Date Picker

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48882].
  {panel}

When creating a JIRA issue dates event, if multiple date types are selected (ex. Due Date and Created Date), the date type does not appear on the calendar. 

If the event is modified to only include a single date type, then the type does appear in the title.

To reproduce:
* Create a "JIRA Issue Dates" event
* Select (for example) "Issue Due Date" and "Issue Created Date"
* The date type doesn't appear in the event titles
* Edit the event and un-select "Issue Created Date"
* The text "(Due Date)" now appears at the end of the issue title

This is a big problem for us because we utilize several custom date fields in our issues, we cannot distinguish between the date types on the calendar without looking at the issue details.

I attached screenshots of how a particular event looks when multiple dates are selected and when a single date is selected.
fields.summary: Date type does not appear in event title when multiple issue dates are selected

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-48870].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Team Calendars only imports .ics files that respects the [RFC-2445|https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2445.txt]. However, the Team Calendars plugin expects that the *end date* exists for every event, which is not actually mandatory according to the mentioned RFC:
{quote}
   2.  A calendar entry with a "DTSTART" property but no "DTEND"
       property does not take up any time. It is intended to represent
       an event that is associated with a given calendar date and time
       of day, such as an anniversary. Since the event does not take up
       any time, it MUST NOT be used to record busy time no matter what
       the value for the "TRANSP" property.
{quote}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install a Team Calendars in your Confluence
# Import a Calendar using the *ConfluenceTeamCalendars_webcal.ics* file attached to this report.

h3. Expected Results
* The Calendars is imported as expected.

h3. Actual Results
* The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-confluence.log file and the Calendar is not imported:
{noformat}
2016-10-24 15:30:05,210 ERROR [ajp-nio-8001-exec-6] [extra.calendar3.xwork.ImportSubCalendarAction] execute Unable to import events of type other
 -- referer: http://quicksilver/confluence/calendar/mycalendar.action | url: /confluence/plugins/calendar/importsubcalendar.action | traceId: cfae990fa67f73ba | userName: admin | action: importsubcalendar
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultActiveObjectsServiceWrapper.createEventEntity(DefaultActiveObjectsServiceWrapper.java:93)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultActiveObjectsServiceWrapper.createEventEntity(DefaultActiveObjectsServiceWrapper.java:77)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.AbstractCalendarDataStore.setSubCalendarContent(AbstractCalendarDataStore.java:1114)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.AbstractPeopleHandlingSubCalendarDataStore.setSubCalendarContent(AbstractPeopleHandlingSubCalendarDataStore.java:124)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.SanboxSubCalendarDataStoreCachingDecorator.setSubCalendarContent(SanboxSubCalendarDataStoreCachingDecorator.java:149)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.calendarstore.DelegatingCalendarDataStore.setSubCalendarContent(DelegatingCalendarDataStore.java:234)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.calendar3.DefaultCalendarManager.setSubCalendarContent(DefaultCalendarManager.java:1808)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:483)
	at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:302)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:190)
	at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:157)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.spring.interceptor.plugin.ExportableInterceptorAdapter$WrappedMethodInvocation.proceed(ExportableInterceptorAdapter.java:53)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.spring.interceptor.spi.SpringInterceptorAdapter$SpringMethodInvocationAdapter.proceed(SpringInterceptorAdapter.java:50)
	at com.atlassian.spring.interceptors.SpringProfilingInterceptor.invoke(SpringProfilingInterceptor.java:16)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.spring.interceptor.spi.SpringInterceptorAdapter.invoke(SpringInterceptorAdapter.java:23)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor1098.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:483)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.util.ContextClassLoaderSettingInvocationHandler.invoke(ContextClassLoaderSettingInvocationHandler.java:26)
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy287.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.plugins.spring.interceptor.plugin.ExportableInterceptorAdapter.invoke(ExportableInterceptorAdapter.java:26)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor1103.invoke(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:483)
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* The code for *DefaultActiveObjectsServiceWrapper.java:93* is:
{code:java}
Date endDate = endDateProperty.getDate();
{code}

h3.Workaround
* Remove the events that do not have DTEND defined, or add a DTEND line for the events in those .ics file.

You may use the [^ics_modified.js] to parse the {{ics}} file to automatically add the {{DTEND}} attribute to those events that are missing.
 # Save the {{ics}} file in a temporary folder.
 # Save the script file in the same folder.
 # Open a terminal window and change directory to the folder above.
 # Run the script providing the filename as an argument and directing the output to another file.
{code}
node ./ics_modified.js iCal.ics > iCal_parsed.ics
{code}
 # [Import|https://confluence.atlassian.com/teamcal/create-add-and-edit-calendars-654213559.html] the parsed {{ics}} file to Confluence.
fields.summary: Cannot Import ICS File When an Event Does Not Have DTEND

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When importing a .ics Calendar that was Exported from Confluence site, attendees are not imported when Importing the Calendar on a different Confluence site.

h3. Environment
* .ics export generated from Confluence TeamCalendars
* Destination site contains the same usernames.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Export from site X a calendar with at least one event with an Attendee.
# Import the calendar on a different Confluence site where that Attendee is a Confluence user.

h3. Expected Results
Team Calendars will match the username during import and add the user as attendee to the event.

h3. Actual Results
Imported Calendar doesn't show attendees for the events.
 
h3. Cause
The import is only mapping the "X-CONFLUENCE-USER-KEY" part of the Attendee in the .ics:
{noformat}
ATTENDEE;X-CONFLUENCE-USER-KEY=ff808081502647c8015064ba7d5e0005;CN=test.username;CUTYPE=INDIVIDUAL:mailto:noreplay@example.com
{noformat}
If it doesn't exist, it doesn't attempt to match with the CN.

h3. Workaround:
Manually change the X-CONFLUENCE-USER-KEY in the Exported Calendar to match the new site values (requires DB access):
Instructions when migrating from A to B
# Create database dump of the list of users of each site. Using Postgres would be:
{noformat}
psql confluence
copy user_mapping(username, user_key) to '/tmp/usermapping.csv' delimiters E'\t' CSV;
{noformat}
Files will look like:
{noformat}
user1        ff80808142c21f330142c2215dd20004
username2        ff80808142c21f330142c2215dd20013
...
{noformat}
# Download them to the same location and name them accordingly: _"usermappingA.csv" "usermappingB.csv"_
# Create a replacement list: (command explained: [here|http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/113898/how-to-merge-two-files-based-on-the-matching-of-two-columns])
{noformat}
awk 'NR==FNR {h[$1] = $2; next} {print $2,$3,h[$1]}' usermappingB.csv usermappingA.csv  > replace.csv
{noformat}
# Manually remove lines from _replace.csv_ that don't have a second parameter. (That means that the user doesn't exist on B)
# Export the calendar/s from A and replace all keys dynamically on the _.ics_ using the _replace.csv_ file: (command explained [here|http://superuser.com/questions/532874/how-to-replace-a-list-of-strings-by-another-list])
{noformat}
while read n k; do sed -i "s/$n/$k/g" calendar.ics; done < replace.csv
{noformat}
# Import Calendar in B
fields.summary: Attendees are not imported to a different Confluence site
